Thank you.

entry.title: The new TDD AI Unit SKU; excellent price point for SAP partners!
entry.content:
In this blog post I want to share some of my thoughts on the new TDD AI Unit SKU recently released by SAP.

In general, I think the new TDD AI Unit offering is very ‚Äúpartner friendly‚Äù First, the price is very low.  SAP has LLM costs every time partners use the AI features, so there is no surprise that SAP at least charge some money for the offering, especially when SAP has the strategy of charging for TDD systems in general. However, compared to productive AI units, the price is very partner friendly and shows that SAP really want to drive AI adoption.   Second, I like the fact that most of the dynamics are the same as for the productive AI units.  The only remark s about the quarterly contract period.  It also makes it a little bit more complex to understand, but it also gives partners more flexibility. 

What is the price of the TDD AI unit?

In short: minimum purchase is 1 block of 100 units with a cost of 65 euro. There are no further discounts possible.   No maximum limit,

With a quarterly contract period, one can argue that the more appropriate positioning of the offering is:  16.25 euro for 25 AI units which expire after 3 months, with auto renewal.

What was just released and why does it matter?

Demoing AI features to customers and prospects is obviously very important for SAP partners in an ‚ÄúBusiness Suite & AI first‚Äù world of SAP. 

We had a temporary partner licensing offering in which partners could use productive AI units for TDD purposes.  With the new specific TDD AI unit SKU we will mainly see two improvements:

  • The TDD AI unit can be ordered by partners in a self-service manner.  No need to reach out to SAP AEs to get a quote.  This simplifies the process and reduces potential delays related to finding an AE, discussing the quote, getting AI units for the right partner account etc
  • The price of the TDD AI unit is significantly lower than the productive AI unit. 

Do I order the TDD AI units In the ‚ÄúManage my services‚Äù app as normal for TDD licenses?

No.  TDD AI Units can only be ordered on SAP store.  SAP is leveraging the SAP store more and more for purchases of customers and partners.  The TDD AI unit is a clear example of this.   You order the TDD AI Unit  SKU 8019670 on this page on the SAP store.  Scroll down on the page and choose ‚ÄúBuy as a partner‚Äù tab.  Then click on ‚ÄúConfigure to see price‚Äù and follow the instructions.

On the SAP store it says ‚ÄúQuantity is measured in blocks of 100 capacity units per year. Due to 3-month contract duration, 25% of the annual units are allocated each quarter. Unused units will expire at the end of each 3-month period". This is different than the productive AI units, right?

Correct, this is different.   The way it works for TDD is a little bit different than for productive AI units.  In general, SAP uses 3 months as the standard contract period for TDD subscriptions.  This is mainly to give partners more flexibility to turn on and off systems dependent on what they need to demo in specific sales cycles.  

For the rest, the rules for TDD AI Units follow the rules of the productive AI units:  the ‚Äúrequest‚Äù capacity per user is the same and the ‚Äúrequest‚Äù cost per AI feature is the same.  These are all described in the TDD AI Features Guide Price List.   The activation process of the AI features follows similar process as for productive AI units

What happens if I want to cancel?

Let‚Äôs say a partner orders 1 block of 100 AI units on 1st January 2026.  Right away, the partner will be charged 16.25 and gets 25 AI units to spend over the next 3 months.     If the partner cancels the contract 30 days before the end of the contract period (which thus is 3 months), nothing else will happen!   Thus, the partner has spent 16.25 euro for having 25 AI units to spend over 3 months.   

If the partner does not cancel the subscription, it will auto-renew, and the partner will be charged 16.25 euro for the next 3 months and again get 25 AI units to spend during those 3 months.

Can I use the new TDD AI Unit SKU for Joule for Consultant?

No.  To run joule for consultant, you need productive AI units.  Read more here.

What can I do with a 1 block of 100 AI units?

Let‚Äôs say you already have core ERP Cloud (public) LOB system on TDD.  Then you can use your 100 units to run one Per User Per Month (PUPM) Financial Management AI user for 1 year.  As the cost of the PUPM package is 8 AI units per month, you need 24 AI units per 3 months and 96 AI units per year.

The calculations are similar for ERP Private Cloud, SCM and CX.   For SuccessFactors you can run 16 users with 100 AI units on yearly basis since a HCM AI PUPM package costs 0.5 AI unit per month.  

These calculations are based on the information in  TDD  AI Features Guide Price List.

For Financial Management PUPM: What will happen with the 1 unit I do not use every 3 months? 

In this case It will just be lost / it will expire at the end of the 3 months if you don‚Äôt find something else to use it for.  My recommendation: use it to run document grounding!!   You will only need 0.6 AI units per 3 months to run 40 documents which should be more than enough for demo purposes.  Read more in  Document Grounding: A (hidden) gem in SAP Business AI‚Äôs portfolio for smaller companies.

As partner, we login to the LOB TDD system with a ‚Äúrole user‚Äù and thus not the consultant‚Äôs name), to demo the SAP solution as a user in a real business role.  Some SAP demo scripts are even built around this concept.  Does this stay the same?

Yes.  this stays the same. 

If this is the way you work with your TDD system, it is obviously important to allocate the AI PUPM packages to the login user names that your staff uses when login to the LOB solution on the TDD environment. You do this in SAP cloud identity service.

After I have ordered the TDD AI Units, what do I need to do to get AI features up and running on my TDD SAP solution instance?

For details regarding the various LOB SAP Solutions, check out the LOB specific guides on this page. There could be some small variations per LOB solution so check the decks.  However, in general the process is:

  • In SAP for me, ‚Äúrequest activation‚Äù for the TDD PUPM package you want
  • In cloud identity services, allocate users to the PUPM Package.
  • In SAP for me, request activation of the AI features you want to use & get the entitlements activated into you LOB solution by SAP.  You need to indicate the TDD instance(s) where you want this to happen. 
  • In the LOB solution itself, grant users right to the individual AI features

 Is it possible that I as partner overuse my AI capacity?

Some background info: each AI PUPM user get a lot of AI capacity (called ‚Äúrequest‚Äù capacity) which should easily cover ‚Äúfair use‚Äù.  For example, for the Financial PUPM user, the request capacity is 5200.

While it is theoretically possible to go over the ‚Äúfair use‚Äù, I think it is highly unlikely because:

  • For productive usage, SAP has calculated these limits with the purpose of them being more than enough for productive usage.  There is no wish that users should overrun. 
  • The request allowance per TDD user is the same as for productive use, and I would expect that partner TDD user will use the features much less than a productive user. A PUPM TDD user will mainly use the AI units to demo (not development or testing, and not high-volume productive use). 
  • Even if one user would overuse, the over usage will be compensated by potential underuse of other users. 

Even if it is very unlikely, what happens if we as partner ‚Äúoveruse‚Äù?

IF there would be an overuse, the existing AI unit balance will be charged for the extra usage. 

Let‚Äôs look at an example: A partner has 5 TDD AI PUPM users in ERP Cloud.  This will cost 26 euro per month (5 users * 8 AI units PUPM * 0.65 euro per unit).  Let‚Äôs assume ALL users overuse by 25% in a month (highly unlikely‚Ä¶).  The extra usage will be 13 AI units (at a cost of 8.45 euro).

Here are the details of the calculations if interested, based on information in the TDD AI Feature Guide Price List:

  • Total allowed request capacity for 5 users: 5 * 5200 = 26.000
  • 25% over usage: 26.000 * 25% = 6.500 request
  • Cost of overage is 2 AI units per 1000 requests over the allowance ->  (6.500 / 1000) * 2 AI units * 0.65 AI unit cost = 8.45 Euro.  

In my opinion, this is not an amount to spend too much time worrying about.  

 Even if it is very unlikely and not costly, what can I do to monitor and manage this?

Planned for Q1 2026, SAP will give visibility in SAP-for-me on details related to TDD AI Unit balances and consumption.  Partners could choose to check these overviews on a regular basis to be comfortable with how it all works.

Since PUPM packages consume AI units every month and not for a year in one go, you can manage the activation and deactivation of users per calendar month.  For example, if you know in December that a consultant with an AI PUPM package assigned will not need access to AI features anymore for a while, you can consider deactivating this user‚Äôs AI PUPM package in SAP identity cloud services before the end of December.  The person will not consume any AI units anymore as of January 1st.   

At the beginning of each new month, SAP will check in SAP cloud identify services how many named users where assigned to the PUPM packages in the previous month, multiply this number this with the monthly PUPM unit cost and subtract the result from your AI unit balance.  

Since partners activate and deactivate users themselves and know the AI unit cost per users per month upfront, they can control and predict the AI consumption themselves.

What if I have a very important question not answered?

You can consider booking an SAP Business AI Licensing & Pricing Advisory services which is free for Gold and Platinum partners.  Else, feel free to reply to this post with a question

If you are interested to learn more about AI unit cost dynamics related topics also important for TDD AI units, consider to read SAP PUPM Business AI: what does it cost to run ONE AI feature ONE time?.  This article is about productive AI units, but many of the dynamics are the same for TDD units.

For more info about SAP Business AI TDD offerings in general, please check out the Partner TDD landing page.

entry.title: Re: Entry doesn't exist in KNB1
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

The problem was solved. Just to iterate, the data was stored on the tables KNA1 and KNB1, yet the issue persist.

The solution was an input (company code) from the screen which used on the program, its value was missing. So, the company code must input first, then input the necessary data and it will be read by the program.

It makes weird on my end because I check the trace of the program and it shows standard program calling KNB1, but I can't debug on it since it is not showing for checking if it's fetching.

 

Thanks, community, for answering my problem.

entry.title: How to Prepare a Deep Payload for Business Partner Master Data (API_BUSINESS_PARTNER)
entry.content:
In this blog, we‚Äôll explore how to prepare deep payloads for the OData V2 API API_BUSINESS_PARTNER in Business Partner for different scenarios.

When integrating with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition or SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition OData APIs, we often need to create or update multiple related entities together ‚Äî such as a Business Partner with its Customer, Supplier, Bank, or Identification details. Instead of multiple sequential API calls,  we can use the Deep Insert concept, allowing us to create related entities in a single request.

We‚Äôll understand what POST and Deep POST calls are in OData, how to analyze metadata, and how to structure payloads for different scenarios ‚Äî such as creating a Business Partner along with a Customer, Supplier, or Bank / Identification details ‚Äî all in a single request.

Understanding the Supported Operations for API_BUSINESS_PARTNER

API_BUSINESS_PARTNER provides the following key operations:
- POST: Create a new business partner record
- GET (READ): Retrieve existing data
- PATCH: Update existing data
- DELETE: Delete a record

A POST call is used to create a single entity.
A Deep POST (Deep Entity) is used to create a parent entity and related child entities together in a single API call.

What is a Deep POST Call?

What is a Deep Payload in Business Partner Creation?

A deep payload = Creating Business Partner + related dependent entities in a single POST.

Example:
Business Partner (root entity) and one or more of the following dependent entities

  • Business Partner Address
  • Customer
  • Customer Company Code
  • Customer Sales Area
  • Supplier
  • Supplier Company
  • Supplier Purchasing Org
  • Communication (Email, Phone)
  • Identification, Tax Numbers, Bank Details

Instead of making multiple API calls, you can send one nested JSON structure containing all relevant data.

Key Entities and Relationships

Below are some of the commonly used entities that can be combined in deep payloads:

Hierarchy Example:
BusinessPartner
 ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ to_BusinessPartnerRole
 ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ to_BusinessPartnerAddress
 ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ to_Customer
 ‚îÇ     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ to_CustomerCompany
 ‚îÇ     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ to_CustomerSalesArea
 ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ to_Supplier
       ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ to_SupplierCompany
       ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ to_SupplierPurchasingOrg

 

Example Scenarios

Here are some typical examples of deep payload combinations:

- Business Partner + Customer
- Business Partner + Supplier
- Business Partner + Bank Details
- Business Partner + Identification Details

 

Understanding Entity Relationship in API_BUSINES_PARTNER 

  1. Open the API on SAP API Business Hub
    This is the best place to understand how Business Partner entities are structured.
    üëâhttps://api.sap.com/api/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/overview

  2. Review the Entity Model or the $metadata
    The metadata file describes all entities, fields, and relationships used in the API.

  3. Check the Metadata URL
    /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/$metadata

  4. Identify Navigation Properties
    Navigation properties show how entities are connected. Examples include:
       to_Customer
       to_Supplier
       to_BusinessPartnerAddress
       to_BusinessPartnerRole

  5. Understand the Root Entity
    The main (parent) entity is A_BusinessPartner.
    All other entities are connected to it through navigation properties.


  6. Child Entities Can Have Their Own Children
    For example:
    A_Customer is a child of A_BusinessPartner
    Under A_Customer, there are further children:



  7. Key Considerations Before Designing Payload
    1. Mandatory Fields

      For Business Partner:

      • BusinessPartnerCategory (e.g., "1" = Person, "2" = Org)
      • LastName / OrganizationName1
      • Country
      • Language

      For Customer:

      • Customer (BP Number or empty for creation)
      • CompanyCode
      • ReconciliationAccount

       For Supplier:

      • PurchasingOrganization
      • OrderingCurrency

    2. Control Flags
      For deep insert:
      • "to_..." navigation properties must be included
      • Omit read-only fields (CreationDate, ChangedBy, etc.)

Step-by-Step: How to Prepare a Deep Payload

  1. Identify the Root Entity - Always A_BusinessPartner for API_BUSINESS_PARTNER (Parent node)
  2. Explore Metadata - via /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/$metadata to see navigation properties
  3. Build the Payload Structure - root = Business Partner, add nested structures for child entities
  4. Prepare and Test Payloads in any third-party API testing tool or SAP Gateway Client (/IWFND/GW_CLIENT)

 

Example 1: Business Partner + Customer Creation 

In this example, a Business Partner and its associated Customer master data are created together using a single deep-create request.
This payload demonstrates how multiple dependent entities‚Äîsuch as business partner general data, Customer company code data, and Customer sales area data‚Äîcan be submitted in one OData call.

{
  "BusinessPartnerCategory": "2",
  "OrganizationBPName1": "ABC Tech Pvt Ltd",
  "BusinessPartnerGrouping": "XXXX",
  "to_BusinessPartnerRole": [
    { "BusinessPartnerRole": "FLCU01" },
    { "BusinessPartnerRole": "FLCU00" }
  ],
  "to_BusinessPartnerAddress": [
    {
      "Country": "IN",
      "CityName": "Bangalore",
      "PostalCode": "XXXX",
      "StreetName": "MG Road",
      "HouseNumber": "XX",
      "Language": "EN",
      "to_EmailAddress": [
        {
          "EmailAddress": "info@XXX.com",
          "IsDefaultEmailAddress": true
        }
      ]
    }
  ],
  "to_Customer": {
    "CustomerAccountGroup": "XXXX",
    "to_CustomerCompany": [
      {"CompanyCode": "XXXX", "ReconciliationAccount": "XXXXXX"}
    ],
    "to_CustomerSalesArea": [
      {
        "SalesOrganization": "0001",
        "DistributionChannel": "01",
        "Division": "01",
        "CustomerPricingProcedure": "1",
        "PriceListType": "01"
      }
    ]
  }
}

 

Example 2: Business Partner + Supplier Creation

In this example, a Business Partner and its associated Supplier master data are created together using a single deep-create request. This payload demonstrates how multiple dependent entities‚Äîsuch as BP general data, Supplier company code data, and Supplier purchasing organization data‚Äîcan be submitted in one OData call.

{
  "BusinessPartnerCategory": "2",
  "OrganizationBPName1": "XYZ Supplies Ltd",
  "BusinessPartnerGrouping": "XXXX",
  "SearchTerm1": "XYZ",
  "to_BusinessPartnerRole": [
    { "BusinessPartnerRole": "FLVN01" },
    { "BusinessPartnerRole": "FLVN00" }
  ],
  "to_BusinessPartnerAddress": [
    {
      "Country": "IN",
      "CityName": "Bangalore",
      "PostalCode": "XXXXXX",
      "StreetName": "MG Road",
      "HouseNumber": "XX",
      "Language": "EN"
    }
  ],
  "to_Supplier": {
    "SupplierAccountGroup": "XXXX",
    "to_SupplierCompany": [
      {
        "CompanyCode": "XXXX",
        "ReconciliationAccount": "XXXXXX"
      }
    ],
    "to_SupplierPurchasingOrg": [
      {
        "PurchasingOrganization": "0001",
        "PurchaseOrderCurrency": "INR"
      }
    ]
  }
}

 

Example 3: Business Partner + Bank/Identification

In this example, a Business Partner is created along with its associated bank account and identification details in a single deep-create request. This payload demonstrates how additional dependent entities, such as bank account assignments, identification numbers, and country-specific ID types, can be submitted together in a single OData call.

{
  "BusinessPartnerCategory": "2",
  "OrganizationBPName1": "ABC Tech Ltd",
  "BusinessPartnerGrouping": "XXXX",
  "to_BusinessPartnerBank": [
    {
      "BankCountryKey": "IN",
      "BankNumber": "XXXXXXXXXX",
      "BankAccount": "XXXXXXXXXX",
      "BankName": "Bank Name"
    }
  ]
}

Identification Details:
{
  "BusinessPartnerCategory": "2",
  "OrganizationBPName1": " ABC Tech Ltd ",
  "BusinessPartnerGrouping": "XXXX",
  "to_BuPaIdentification": [
    {
      "BPIdentificationType": "XXX",
      "BPIdentificationNumber": "XXXXXXXXXX",
      "ValidityStartDate": "2023-01-01T00:00:00",
      "ValidityEndDate": "9999-12-31T00:00:00"
    }
  ]
}

 

An alternate way of preparing a payload

Sometimes it isn't easy to write a Deep Payload from scratch because there are many parent‚Äìchild entities. An easy method is to read an existing Business Partner and copy its structure to prepare your payload.

Here is how you can do it:

Step 1: Use a GET call with $expand to see the full structure

If you want to create a Business Partner along with Supplier details, Company Code details, or Purchasing Org details, you can first read an existing business partner record that already has those values. 

You do this using a GET call with $expand to include all related child entities. 

Example URI: 

/sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/A_BusinessPartner('XXXXXXXXXX') 

?$expand=to_Supplier,to_Supplier/to_SupplierCompany,to_Supplier/to_SupplierPurchasingOrg

This reads the Business Partner along with: 

  • Supplier Header 
  • Supplier Company Code details 
  • Supplier Purchasing Organization details 

Step 2: Copy the Response Payload Using Available Tools

For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

  • SAP Business Accelerator Hub (API Hub) ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù feature 
  • Any third-party API testing tool 
  • SAP API Sandbox 
  • Any REST tool supported in your landscape 

For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition:

You can use the SAP Gateway Client (/IWFND/GW_CLIENT): 

  • Execute the GET call 
  • After receiving the response, choose ‚ÄúUse as Request‚Äù 
  • The tool automatically copies the JSON body into the request editor 

Now you have a ready-made payload template. 

Step 3: Modify the Payload for Your POST Request 

After copying the response: 

  • Remove key fields (like Business Partner number) 
  • Remove read-only values (like CreatedBy, CreationDate) 
  • Change the values to what you want to create 
  • Keep only the nodes you need 

This approach makes your payload correct and aligned with metadata automatically. 

 

Why is this method useful?

This method is simple because:

  • You don‚Äôt need to know the navigation properties
  • You don‚Äôt have to build a JSON structure yourself
  • You avoid mistakes in hierarchy
  • You get a real working example from the system itself

Even someone new to the business partner API can follow this approach.

Below is a visual representation of the typical workflow while using the alternative approach to create a business partner record with a deep payload.

Testing and Validation

Use any API testing tool or SAP Gateway Client to test the Deep POST operation.

URL: /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_BUSINESS_PARTNER/A_BusinessPartner
Method: POST
Headers: Content-Type: application/json, Accept: application/json

Conclusion

To prepare any deep or complex payload:

  • Read the parent‚Äìchild structure from the metadata
  • Identify which navigation properties are needed
  • Build your JSON payload using the same hierarchy
  • Use SAP API Business Hub as a reference for field names, structures, and samples

Deep POST (Deep Insert) allows you to create parent + child entities in a single API request. This approach simplifies integration, ensures consistency, and minimizes the number of API calls.

entry.title: Public Cloud Internal Supplier Integration with EDI
entry.content:
Introduction

The traditional IDoc structure and the process of posting offsetting (clearing) incoming invoices, which have been used for years in on-premise systems, have significantly evolved in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. With the introduction of standardized communication arrangements in the Public Cloud, EDI integrations are now utilized more actively and efficiently.

For instance, in on-premise environments, I have implemented the offsetting invoice posting process using the RD04 invoice output for many years. However, this approach is being replaced in the cloud with more integrated and automated communication frameworks.

1         Prerequisites

For EDI Output, 2EL scopes and for EDI Input, 2EJ scopes must be activated.

To configure the EDI integration, users require the following business roles in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition:

  • Administrator (SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR)
  • Business Integration Expert (SAP_BR_CONF_EXPERT_BUS_NET_INT)
  • Master Data Specialist (SAP_BR_BUPA_MASTER_SPECIALIST)

2         Preparation

This document describes additional configuration steps that must be carried out by customers to activate the Integration of Sales with External Buyers (2EL) and Procurement with External Suppliers (2EJ) scope item. Since these configuration steps are customer-specific, they can't be delivered by SAP.

3         Business Partners

Table for Organization

 

Buyer Company (Purchase Process)

Supplier Company (Sales Process)

Company Code

17US

10US

Partner

1000000 10US Company Partner

36100002 17US Company Partner

First, a business partner is created for the supplier company code and expanded to the purchasing company code.

Next, a partner is created for the purchasing company code and expanded to the supplier company code. During this expansion, the supplier business partner number is entered as a 10-character number in the Account at Customer field within the relevant business partner.

4         Configuration

4.1      Assign Tax Code

The tax rate to be used in the purchase invoice is determined for the tax indicator in the incoming requests.

ƒ∞mplementation Activities: Procurement -> Invoice Management -> Communication for Invoice Management -> Assign Tax Codes for the Transfer of Supplier Invoices

4.2      Program Parameters

In Configure Program Parameters, you specify the required program parameter configuration IDs. Each ID contains the relevant program parameters for posting a supplier invoice.

ƒ∞mplementation Activities: Procurement -> Invoice Management -> Communication for Invoice Management -> Configure and assign program parameters

Assign Program Parameters

In Assign Program Parameters, the generated Parameter ID is assigned to the supplier. This determines which parameter a supplier will proceed with.

4.3      Assign Company Code

In the requests, the company code name determines which company code will be used to create the relevant purchase invoice.

Note: The Company Code Name here represents the Payer addressee on the sales invoice.

4.4      Communications

A User to be used in integrations is created within the Maintain Communication Users app.

A new system is created within the Communication System app. This system will contain information about the system that will communicate.

Enter the user created above in the Inbound User and Outbound User sections. In the Business Partners section, the important point here is to enter the relevant paying partner number.

Following the sales invoice, the SAP_COM_0223 scenario is created for the SAP system exit phase. The previously created System is assigned to this scenario.

In our structure, we will use the SAP_COM_0223 scenario for the Customer Invoice service, but I am sharing other paths for the services below so that they can be used in other integrations where they are stored as desired.

  • Sales Order/Customer Return - Confirm Processing (B2B)

/sap/bc/srt/scs_ext/sap/orderconfirmationrequest_in

  • Outbound Delivery - Notify (B2B)

/sap/bc/srt/scs_ext/sap/deliveryrequest_in

  • Customer Invoice - Send (B2B)

/sap/bc/srt/scs_ext/sap/invoicerequest_in

To ensure that incoming requests are entered into the SAP system, the SAP_COM_0224 scenario is created. The relevant system, System, is assigned to this scenario, which is the default system on the Communication System screen.

The path to be entered for the Purchase Order - Send, Update, Cancel Service is as follows.

/sap/bc/srt/scs_ext/sap/orderrequest_in

4.5      Reports and Logs

Using Fiori Launchpad, users can assign relevant EDI scenarios within the Assign Recipients to Users app, ensuring that only designated users can monitor their EDI logs.

The /SDEDI namespace must be added for EDI outputs and the /MMEDI namespace for EDI inputs.

EDI requests can be tracked within the Message Dashboard app.

Conclusion

The transition from traditional IDoc-based processes in on-premise systems to modern communication scenarios in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition, represents a significant advancement in the way EDI integrations are handled. By leveraging standardized communication arrangements such as SAP_COM_0223 and SAP_COM_0224, organizations can achieve streamlined and automated invoice processing between sales and procurement processes.

This document has outlined the essential prerequisites, business partner configurations, and system communication settings required to enable seamless integration between external buyers and suppliers using scope items 2EL and 2EJ. Through proper assignment of tax codes, program parameters, and communication users, businesses can ensure accurate and efficient invoice exchange across systems.

entry.title: Displaying HTML-Formatted Text in SAP Adobe Forms
entry.content:
Using HTML tags inside long texts or paragraphs in SAP Adobe Forms can be achieved with a few simple steps. In many business scenarios, it becomes necessary to display text with different formatting‚Äîsuch as bold, italic, or underlined within Adobe form outputs. In this blog, we will learn how to accomplish this using OTR text in the SAP system.


Requirement:
To embed HTML tags within long texts or paragraphs and use them in an SAP Adobe Form so that the final output renders the correct formatting.
Based on business needs, the letter or paragraph may include bold, italic, or underlined text to highlight important information.

Scenario:
Display a letter to be printed along with a customer invoice, showing the amount to be paid. The letter must include HTML tags to emphasize specific parts of the content.

Step 1: Create OTR Text Using Transaction SOTR_EDIT

  1. Open Transaction SOTR_EDIT and create a long text/paragraph that contains the required HTML tags.

  2. Select the Long Text radio button and provide an Alias for your text.

  3. Click on Create.

You will then be taken to the next screen. Here:

  • Choose a package in which the OTR text will be saved.

  • Select Object Type = CPUB.

  • At the bottom, enter the paragraph containing all required HTML tags.

After entering the text, check the Text and Alias, then click Save.
Once saved, a Concept string will be generated‚Äînote this value, as it will be needed to retrieve the OTR text in the Adobe Form interface.

Step 2: Form Interface Setup (SFP)

  1. Create a new interface using transaction SFP.

  2. In the interface initialization, fetch the OTR text using class CL_SOTR and the generated concept key.

  3. Store the retrieved text in a string field (e.g., GV_STRING), which will be mapped to the form.

 

DATA : lv_amount TYPE string.

" Get the total amount and invoiced on date for the given invoice number
SELECT SINGLE invdocno, total_amt, crdate FROM dfkkinvdoc_h INTO @DATA(ls_invoice) WHERE invdocno = '400000000001'.

" Create a new instance of CL_SOTR
DATA(lo_sotr) = NEW cl_sotr( i_langu = sy-langu ).
IF lo_sotr IS BOUND.
  lo_sotr->get_string(
    EXPORTING
      i_concept = 'F6D1CC75908F1FD0B49BB1450AAA5BA0'                 " Key for Logical Object in OTR
    IMPORTING
      e_text    = gv_string
  ).
ENDIF.

" Change the dynamic values of gv_string here like amount and invoice date
IF gv_string IS NOT INITIAL.
  REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '&dte' IN gv_string WITH sy-datum.
  REPLACE '&inv_date' IN gv_string WITH ls_invoice-crdate.

  " convert the amount first to strin and then add else it will throw error
  lv_amount = CONV #( ls_invoice-total_amt ).
  REPLACE '&amount' IN gv_string WITH lv_amount.

  REPLACE '[Your Company Name]' IN gv_String WITH sy-uname.
ENDIF.

Step 3: Design the Adobe Form

  1. Create the Adobe Form using the interface built in Step 2.

  2. Drag and drop the GV_STRING element into the form‚Äôs design layout.

  3. Adjust layout and margins as required.

  4. Important: Change the field type to Rich Text instead of plain text.


Step 4: Add JavaScript for HTML Rendering

To properly render HTML formatting in the Adobe form, add a small JavaScript snippet in the calculate event of the text field (GV_STRING).

This JS converts the incoming string into XFA-compatible rich text so that bold, italic, underline, and other tags are displayed correctly.

 

 var envelope = "<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?>" +
    "<exData contentType='text/html' xmlns='http://www.xfa.org/schema/xfa-template/2.8/'" +
    "><body xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml' xmlns:xfa='http://www.xfa.org/schema/xfa-data/1.0/' " +
    "xfa:APIVersion='Acroform:2.7.0.0' xfa:spec='2.1'>" +
    "<p>" + this.rawValue + "</p></body></exData>";

this.value.exData.loadXML(envelope,1,1);

 

 

Step 5: Execute and Validate

Run the form and generate the output PDF.
You will observe that all HTML tags‚Äîsuch as <b>, <i>, and <u> are rendered properly, and the text appears exactly as formatted in the OTR paragraph.

Conclusion

Implementing HTML tags in SAP Adobe Forms is both flexible and efficient when handled through OTR texts. By maintaining the formatting directly in the OTR long text and rendering it via JavaScript in the form, you avoid the complexities of embedding HTML manually within code. This approach keeps the logic clean, leverages standard SAP tools, and ensures consistent formatting across your form outputs.

If you have alternative approaches, suggestions, or enhancements based on your project experience, I‚Äôd be glad to hear them.

Thank you,
Shubham

entry.title: What's new in SAP Cloud Application Programming Model ‚Äì November 2025
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

welcome to the November edition of our SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) release communications blog post! This blog post highlights some of the key features and improvements that we believe will be beneficial to your development processes. To explore these enhancements in depth, check out the details of what's new!

 

New Status Transition Flows Feature Now Available

At reCAP 2025, we have presented a first lab preview of our new status transition flows feature, which simplifies the process of managing workflows in CAP. Over the last months, we have consistently improved it, as you can see in the lab preview presented at Devtoberfest 2025. Now, we are pleased to announce the beta release of this new status transition flows feature.

Many applications require workflows with different statuses - such as "open," "accepted," or "rejected"- and transitions between them. Previously, implementing these status transition flows in CAP required significant manual work. Developers had to define statuses and transitions in the CDS model, implement business logic handlers, configure UI behavior, and maintain consistency across all these components when changes occurred. For complex real-world scenarios, this often resulted in extensive code maintenance.

 With the introduction of the status transition flows feature, much of this manual effort is eliminated. You can now define your status transitions using three simple CDS annotations:

  • '@flow.status': Marks the status property.
  • '@from' and '@to': Specify the transitions from one status to another.

The system automatically registers the necessary handlers for checking entry conditions ('@from') and setting target states ('@to'). Additionally, the required UI annotations are created.

While the generated logic provides a robust framework, you retain the flexibility to override it as needed, ensuring maximum customization. For a comprehensive understanding of this new feature, we encourage you to consult our detailed documentation.

 

The new CAP Console

The new CAP Console addresses common developer frustrations by simplifying deployment and monitoring for SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) applications on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP). Built as an evolution of the Developer Dashboard for Java, this tool supports both Java and JavaScript projects. It offers features like the automatic detection of running CAP projects, a "Remember Project" function and customizable project views to keep your workspace organized.

The deployment process is streamlined through step-by-step guidance, which includes SAP BTP authentication, account selection, and resource availability checks. Developers can choose between deploying directly within the console or using terminal commands.

For monitoring, the CAP Console delivers a graphical overview of application components, real-time performance metrics, and integrated log viewing with adjustable log levels. It also facilitates easy switching between different environments, such as development, testing, and production, with configurations stored in git-friendly YAML files. And it maintains security by leveraging existing SAP BTP permissions and secure SSH tunnels. The tool is available for download from SAP Tools, aiming to reduce the operational overhead for developers and allow them to focus more on coding rather than managing deployments and monitoring. To find out more, please refer to the following blog post: Simplify Deployment and Monitoring with the CAP Console.

 

Recent Advancements in the Attachments Plugin

The SAP Cloud Application Programming Model's (CAP) Attachments plugin has received significant updates, further enhancing its functionality and usability for developers. This plugin, which enables developers to add file upload and management capabilities to their applications with minimal code, has been widely adopted by the community. We are happy to tell you that we now upgraded this plugin based on developer feedback about missing features, documentation gaps, and bugs.

Both, Node.js (v 3.4.0 onwards) and Java versions (v 1.2.2 onwards) of the plugin now offer multi-cloud support, malware scanning for uploaded attachments, and enhanced monitoring and logging capabilities. The Node.js plugin includes additional features such as multi-tenancy support for all storage providers, dynamic visibility control for UI attachments panels, and SAPUI5 validation methods for maximum file size and accepted media types.

The updates also include comprehensive documentation updates for both plugins, ensuring developers have access to current and accurate information. For further information please read the following blog post: Major updates to the Attachments plugin ‚Äì multi-cloud support, malware scanning and more.

 

Further Readings & Events

Simplified Deployment to Kyma

We have recently introduced enhancements that simplify deploying CAP applications to the SAP BTP Kyma runtime, including a streamlined project setup via the new 'cds add kyma' command, interactive credential prompts during deployment with 'cds up -2 k8s', automatic building of SAPUI5 applications, optimized builds, and removal of the need for the standalone containerize tool. For further details please read this blog post written by my colleague Rupa Maity: Streamlined Kyma deployment for CAP applications.

 

Using CAP for Enterprise Data Streaming

With the Streaming DB API, CAP enables scalable deep data exports and streaming imports without loading large datasets into memory. A recent LinkedIn post written by Holger Sch√§fer details how this feature was used to build a deep export and streaming import extension for the CAP Bookshop sample, including SAP Fiori V4 integration. The solution supports capabilities like JSON deep exports and flat CSV exports, and more. For a full technical breakdown and example code, read the original post on LinkedIn.

 

SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Customer Roundtable

As we approach the end of the year, we invite you to join the upcoming CAP Customer Roundtable on December 17th, 2025, at 10 AM CET. This session will provide an overview of some of the latest features, insightful demos, and discussions on questions from the CAP community. Please refer to this blog post for additional details, including the agenda and dial-in information.

 

CAP at SAP TechEd 2025 and Devtoberfest 2025

The fall of 2025 brought two significant events for the SAP development community: Devtoberfest 2025 and SAP TechEd 2025. At SAP TechEd 2025, CAP was highlighted in several sessions, including keynotes and strategy talks that focused on AI-assisted development tools and the evolving role of developers. Devtoberfest 2025 dedicated Fridays to CAP, offering a range of sessions from practical enablement to forward-looking demos, covering topics such as building enterprise-grade CAP applications, integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition APIs, and many other great features. Find an overview on the CAP related highlights at both events here: CAP Highlights from TechEd 2025 and Devtoberfest 2025 ‚Äì a Recap.

 

For further information on new features, please have a look at the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model Release Notes. If you want to stay up-to-date with news, learning resources, and product and strategy updates for CAP: follow our tag in the SAP Community.

We look forward to seeing how you use these new capabilities to create innovative solutions and drive your projects forward. Stay tuned for more updates and happy coding! üòä

entry.title: Re: SAP AVC characteristics not able to remove from the c...
entry.content:
Good day @arturo_suarez

Apologies for the delayed response. To ensure your follow-up questions are correctly directed , please ensure to use the @ options to tag the person.

Following up on your question, the public cloud does not allow you to delete a characteristics that you have already used in configuration. The system tries to protect historical data consistency and therefore blocks you from deleting it.

Even with an ECN, you will still have some restrictions except:

  • You select the correct Change Type and Object Tpyes in the change master.
  • The chosen change number is valid for the classification object and your navigation to classification context is correct.

These steps should enable you delete once you have set the change number and object properly. Should you still not be able to delete it, then ensure as mentioned above that the characteristics has not been used in any active configuration.

Step 1:

In your ECN, the change type to choose is 300 and your validity date should be today or in the future, then save it.

Step 2:

In your ECN, open your change number, go to object types tab, ensure you select/check the classification checkbox, make sure the object type row is not greyed out and save.

Step 3:

In your Manage Classes app, enter your class,

go to characteristics tab, enter the change number at the top.

Now you should be able to delete. Either you delete the characteristics or you set the status to inactive if deletion is still restricted. You can do that by using the Display values icon to confirm usage dependencies should you not be able to delete.

Should you still face issues with deleting it after fulfilling those requirements, I suggest you raise a ticket with SAP.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Becoming a Data Architect: Your First Step in the Data Architecture Learning Journey
entry.content:
In an era where data drives innovation, strategy, and transformation, Data Architecture has become the cornerstone of enterprise success. To bridge the gap between technical expertise and strategic impact, SAP Data Architecture experts and the SIX learning team have collaborated to introduce the "Becoming a Data Architecture Course (Foundational)," the first stage in the "Becoming a Data Architect" program.  
 
This course empowers aspiring architects, data professionals, data solution experts, and Data enthusiasts to master the principles, paradigms, and frameworks that define modern enterprise data architecture. 
 
Overview of the Learning 
 
The Data Architecture course is structured as a learning pyramid, designed to build expertise layer by layer ‚Äî from foundational principles to strategic business impact. 
 
At its base lies Unit 1: Foundational Concepts, which anchors learners in the essential principles of modelling, metadata management, and architectural alignment. It serves as the bedrock upon which all modern data paradigms and governance strategies are built. You will understand the basic terminology and fundamentals of Data Architecture, including conceptual, logical, and physical data models, which ensure efficiency and scalability. Understand what metadata and semantic management are and how data architecture integrates with enterprise architecture frameworks such as Zachman and TOGAF. 
In the second unit (Unit 2: Modern Paradigms & Integration), we cover contemporary data architecture patterns, including Data Mesh, Data Fabric, Data Lake, and Data Lakehouse, and compare them based on different considerations. The unit also explores integration and pipeline approaches, such as ETL and ELT, and when to use each.  
In Unit 3: Governance, Security & Strategic Impact ‚Äì we cover details of establishing comprehensive data governance frameworks (including stewardship and data lineage) and integrate security and privacy controls to ensure compliance with relevant regulations and secure AI/ML use cases. As data ecosystems grow, governance and security become the bedrock of trust and compliance. This unit develops your ability to design, secure, and align enterprise data strategies. 
And finally, in Unit 4, Communicating Data Value: A great architect not only designs systems, but they also inspire transformation. This final unit reinforces the communication and leadership skills necessary to effect change. We talk about how you can communicate Architectural Value: Articulate the limitations of the current data landscape ("as-is") and present a compelling, business-focused narrative for the benefits of the proposed future-state ("to-be") architecture (quality, cost, scale).  
 
Who Should Take This Course
 
This course is designed for data professionals at every stage of their career who want to evolve from technical roles into strategic architectural leadership. Ideal participants include, but are not limited to:  
  1. Data Engineers and Modellers seeking to advance into architectural roles. 
  2. Solution and Enterprise Architects aiming to strengthen their data design and governance foundations. 
  3. Business Intelligence and Analytics professionals who need to understand how architecture underpins data-driven decision-making. 
  4. IT and Transformation leaders looking to align data systems with business outcomes. 
 
Why take this course? 
Because modern organisations need architects who understand both technology and business value. By mastering foundational architecture principles, you‚Äôll: 
  1. Improve data discoverability, quality, and governance. 
  2. Learn how to connect data architecture to enterprise goals. 
  3. Gain the credibility to influence strategic data decisions. 
  4. Prepare for the SAP Certified Data Architect* specialization that is planned for launch in 2026 
 
How to Start Your Course
You can get started today without any prerequisites via the learning.sap.com: Becoming an SAP Data Architect (Foundational)  
But this is just a starting point - Becoming a Data Architect is not just about mastering tools or technologies‚Äîit‚Äôs about developing architectural thinking. This Foundational Concepts course sets the stage for you to evolve into a strategic leader who can design, communicate, and drive data transformation in any organization.  
 
In 2026, we plan to launch the Data Architecture Advanced course and Data Architect Certification (C_BDCDA), which will provide you with a comprehensive path to becoming a skilled Data Architect.  
 
Ready to begin? 
Visit SAP Learning and enrol in the Becoming an SAP Data Architect ‚Äì Foundational course today!

entry.title: Re: Direct configuration in test tenant/production tenant
entry.content:
Dear @snigdhodeep,

The Lexicographical indicator in Define Output Format of Material Numbers (102320) cannot be switched ON or OFF once any purely numeric product/material numbers exist in that system. SAP blocks it with message BMG265 (Numeric material numbers already exist in system) because changing the rule would make existing numbers ambiguous / not interpretable

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003516603

In Public Cloud (3-system landscape) you also can‚Äôt just maintain it directly in Test/Production to bypass transports, business configuration is provided via SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC) connected to DEV, and then moved via the transport tools/process to Test/Prod

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003482742

In my opinion you have two options:

Option A: Recommended if you‚Äôre still in implementation / test data)

To change the Lexicographical setting, you must get to a state where no numeric product numbers have been used yet. SAP own guidance is archive/remove the numeric materials first only then can you change the indicator. In real projects this usually means one of these approaches depending on what‚Äôs feasible in your tenant and how much dependent data exists:

  • Refresh/reset the DEV/customizing tenant or request a clean tenant and set Lexicographical before any product creation/migration, then re-migrate
  • If you already created products and even transactions, deletion is often messy the clean tenant + re-load approach is usually the least risky

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0003516603

Option B: Accept SAP product number behavior and introduce a business-facing ID for example Custom Field. If you cannot remove those numeric product numbers, then you cannot solve this by changing Lexicographical so a workaround can be:

  • Add/repurpose a field for the business product code that must keep meaningful leading zeros for example a dedicated custom field like ZZ_EXT_PROD_CODE or a standard legacy/old product number style field if it fits your governance
  • Use that field in:
    • migration templates / interfaces,
    • search/display in Fiori apps as a visible column and filter,
    • outputs/printing/integration mappings

This is the only safe path if production data must remain intact.

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: AI-Assisted User Learning and Change Management is ready
entry.content:
Sometimes in SAP projects, I meet people who look at the long list of tools we have today and ask a completely reasonable question: ‚ÄúWe already use Joule. We already use SAP Enable Now. We already use WalkMe. Do we really need something else for user learning?‚Äù

If you are not an L&D specialist, this question makes perfect sense. At first glance, everything seems to overlap. And this is usually the moment where curiosity starts, because something feels unclear, even for experienced project leaders.

What most people don‚Äôt see is everything that happens long before training materials appear on the screen. We all know the visible part: videos, simulations, in-app guidance, Joule answering questions.

But behind the scenes, there is a much harder challenge that quietly decides whether a project succeeds or fails. It‚Äôs the work of figuring out what users actually need to learn. Not in theory, but in their company, with their processes, their roles, their variations, with their data and their way of working. This part is slow, manual, and often messy. And people only realize how heavy it is once they sit down and try to build a training plan from scratch.

This is the gap the AI-assisted user learning and change management app is designed to fill. It doesn‚Äôt try to replace Joule or WalkMe or SAP Enable Now. It solves a completely different problem; one that these tools don‚Äôt address.

While Joule helps users on the spot when they have a question, and WalkMe and SAP Enable Now help deliver learning and guidance, none of them tells you what the learning should look like in the first place unless you spend considerable amount of effort to achieve that golden goal. 

User adoption often becomes harder than expected because the real challenge is not creating training materials; it is understanding what people actually need to learn. And this understanding must come from the organization‚Äôs trusted sources of truth: the business processes designed in SAP Signavio, the user stories written during the project, the test cases stored in SAP Cloud ALM, and all the other documents teams create along the way. Bringing these pieces together, making sense of them, and turning them into clear learning steps for every role is slow, if manual, and easy to get wrong. This hidden work is the real reason training becomes complicated and why projects struggle to keep learning aligned, accurate, and up to date.

This is exactly where the AI-assisted user learning and change management app steps in; it connects all these sources, analyzes them, and helps transform complex project information into a structured, role-based learning path that users can follow.

The simplest way I can describe it is this: the app gives direction. Joule supports users in the moment. WalkMe and SAP Enable Now bring the training to life. Each one has its own job. When they‚Äôre used together, they make the learning experience smoother, clearer, and far easier to manage‚Äîboth for learners and for the teams delivering the project.

If you‚Äôre not from the learning world, skepticism is normal. But once you see the hidden work behind user adoption, the value becomes obvious. Most of the pain in training doesn‚Äôt come from producing content. It comes from figuring out what the content should be.

For the first time, this can be automated. And that is why the AI-assisted user learning and change management app is not ‚Äúanother tool.‚Äù It's the complementary link that ties everything together and turns learning into something that finally fits the real world of SAP projects.

The AI-assisted user learning and change management app is commercially available (in limited delivery through the Early Adopter Care program) starting December 8th, 2025, making this capability accessible to SAP customers.

Key resources

  • Custom LNA

  • Prepare Learning Content
  • SAP Store 
  • SAP Discovery Center ‚Äì AI Feature
  • SAP Business AI Estimator

entry.title: Understanding PO Deletion and Service Entry Behavior in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi Team,

Could you please assist in confirming whether our understanding is accurate?

Limit PO (Services)

  • ECC Behavior: Deletion is not permitted after invoicing; this ensures strict audit control.
  • S/4HANA Public Cloud Behavior: Deletion is allowed even after invoicing.

Rationale for Standard Behavior

  • Material vs. Service POs
    • Material POs: Deletion is restricted post-invoice to preserve inventory and valuation accuracy.
    • Service Limit POs: These framework POs do not affect inventory postings, so SAP permits deletion after invoicing as it does not impact stock or material ledger.

Main Reasons

  • Services do not impact inventory.
  • Allows flexibility for recurring or contract-based services.
  • Invoices remain valid in FI even if the PO is deleted.

Blocked PO Line

  • ECC Behavior: Changes are restricted once the line is blocked.
  • S/4HANA Public Cloud Behavior: Service Entry updates and deletions remain possible.

Rationale for Standard Behavior

  • Blocking a PO line prevents new procurement actions but does not prohibit modifications to service entries.
  • Service Entry Sheets (SES) validate service delivery and impact accounting, not inventory.
  • SAP allows SES corrections for enhanced flexibility and audit compliance.

Design Rationale

  • Materials: Stringent controls are in place due to inventory and valuation considerations.
  • Services: More flexibility is provided as these do not affect stock.
  • Blocking halts new confirmations but permits adjustments to existing SES for accuracy.

ECC vs S/4HANA Public Cloud Behavior Comparison

Scenario ECC Behavior S/4HANA Public Cloud Behavior

Standard PONo deletion after invoicing; audit trail maintainedDeletion not allowed after invoicing
Limit PO (Services)No deletion after invoicing; strict audit controlDeletion allowed even after invoicing (by design)
Blocked PO LineChanges restricted once blockedService Entry updates/deletes still possible

Regards,

Sai.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Assign G/L Account Ranges to Semantic Tags
entry.content: Assigning G/L account ranges to semantic tags isn‚Äôt supported. To proceed, either assign the semantic tag at the FSV item level so all accounts under the node inherit it, or remove the account range from the FSV and list the accounts individually so each one can be tagged separately.

entry.title: Re: SAP Business One for HANA Client Hangs Permanently on...

entry.title: Dynamic Font Styling in Adobe Forms (JavaScript)
entry.content:
Introduction:
In many business scenarios, Adobe Forms need to highlight specific information dynamically‚Äîsuch as marking certain values in bold, keeping others in normal, or changing the emphasis based on data conditions. Instead of hard-coding text styles, we can control the font style at runtime using simple logic. This approach makes the form more readable, user-friendly, and aligned with business rules.

while assigning font style in adobe forms we have provision to select font style thats applied each of the data, but what if i has to maintain dynamically means based on condition? this blog will gives solution.

Solution Overview:
To implement dynamic font styling in Adobe Forms, the value to be evaluated is passed into the form, and a small JavaScript condition is added in the text field‚Äôs event (such as initialize or exit). In this script, the field‚Äôs value is checked, and based on the condition, the font weight is adjusted at runtime. For example, if the value equals ‚ÄúGTARLANA,‚Äù the script sets the text to bold, otherwise it applies a normal font style. This simple logic allows the form to adapt its appearance dynamically without modifying the layout each time a new rule is introduced.

if ( this.rawValue === "GTARLANA" ){
       this.font.weight = "bold"
       };
       else{
       this.font.weight = "normal" };

Output:

 

When condition Satisfied

 

When condition not Satisfied

 



Conclusion:
Dynamic font styling in Adobe Forms provides a clean way to highlight important data without complicating the form layout. By controlling style through conditions, you maintain a single design while achieving dynamic visual emphasis. This approach is simple, reusable, and enhances the clarity of printed business documents.

entry.title: Re: How can I get a complete list of sub-scope items prog...
entry.content:
Hello,

Sorry for the delay in getting back to you,

If this is still relevant, the most effective "single downloadable file" approach is to use a structured export report directly from SAP Signavio Process Manager, as this is the primary source for detailed process modeling. You should use the Process Characteristics Report with Detailed Elements from SAP Signavio Process Manager.  This report generates an Excel file (XLS) containing a structured, tabular view of all elements and attribute values within the selected diagrams.

This report will also help you to get the applications (Apps) and roles associated with each process step (sub-scope item), you rely on the same comprehensive data sources used above, provided that the required linkages are maintained as attributes or relationships in your tools.

For this to work efficiently, the roles and applications must be modeled as attributes (standard or custom) associated with the respective BPMN elements (tasks, sub-processes, etc.) in SAP Signavio Process Manager.

 

If your organization relies on SAP LeanIX to model the complex relationships between processes, applications, and roles (a key function of Enterprise Architecture Management), using its APIs is the best programmatic approach:
SAP LeanIX Data Model: The process structure (sub-scope items) is documented on the Business Context Fact Sheet, and these Fact Sheets can be explicitly linked to:
    ‚ó¶ Applications (Apps): Using the direct relationship between Business Context (Process) and Application Fact Sheets.
    ‚ó¶ Roles: Roles are often modeled as Organization Fact Sheet subtypes (like "Team" or "Business Unit"), which are linked to applications, or as Subscription Roles (Responsible/Accountable) on the Fact Sheets themselves.
‚Ä¢API Usage: You can use the GraphQL API or the OData Integration to query these complex, multi-layered relationships in bulk.
 
You can then queries relationships between Process Fact Sheets (sub-scope items), Application Fact Sheets, and associated Organization/User Group data in bulk, mitigating manual effort/slow file downloads.
 
Do not hesitate to reach out to the following email to get further support: signavio_success@sap.com
Best,

entry.title: Re: How to Calculate VAT for PO and get in the Standard f...
entry.content:
Good day @Yathurshika_Sathiyavarman

The BAdI you are using has limited access to the pricing and tax condition values. Direct access to condition types like MWST is not provided in it.

The error you experienced often refers to improper syntax or usage of fields that are not available in that context.

You cannot directly retrieve Tax, Net or Gross Amount by using the BAdI you mentioned in public cloud because pricing data is not available at this enhancement point.

I recommend following the extensibility-compliant method:

Step 1:

Create a CDS view with I_PurchseOrderItemAPI01 and associate it with A_PurOrdPricingElement to retrieve condition values and filter it for VAT-relevant condition types in the CDS logic or within the Form.

Step 2:

You need to extend your PO Form Data Source. Use the Maintain Form Template Data Source Extensions. Here, choose MM_PUR_PO_OUTPUT, create a new extension by joining your CDS and the item and publish.

Step 3:

In the Manage Form Templates App, copy MM_PUR_PURCHASE_ORDER, download the Adobe Lifecycle Designer, add your Custom VAT field and add sum logic for VAT in Adobe (e.g., JavaScript logic)

Step 4:

Finally upload the form template you modified back into the Manage Form Templates App, assign it to the MM_PUR_PO_OUTPUT type and ensure your communication arrangement and output channel are active.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to get ModelID in Signavio Process Governance?
entry.content:
Hello

The most likely cause of the "ModelID is not defined" error is that the modelID variable is not properly defined or not available in the JavaScript task. In Process Governance, workflow variables must be explicitly defined and selected before a script can use them.

  1. Check variable access in the script task, make sure modelID is selected in the task configuration. If it isn‚Äôt included as an input, the script cannot read it and the error appears.

  2. Make sure the Model ID is provided earlier in the workflow, for example by the workflow trigger or a previous action that passes the model ID and revision ID.

  3. Use the SAP Signavio Process Manager API client in your script, import the library, then query the model details using the modelID once the variable is correctly passed.

If this did not help please reach out to signavio_success@sap.com

Best,

entry.title: SAP Utilities Roadmap 2026 Onwards
entry.content:
The utilities industry will continue to play a key role in SAP‚Äôs strategy and product development. It is therefore important for us to keep customers, partners, and the entire SAP Utilities ecosystem informed about our planned innovations.

As in previous years, we have created a matrix outlining the relevant industry topics and their corresponding innovations. This matrix represents a selection of the most important innovations and does not claim to be exhaustive.

Additional innovations may be added over time, and delivery timelines remain subject to change. Following a high-level overview of the highlights, we provide detailed information for each topic. For nearly all innovations, a link to the SAP Roadmap Explorer is included for further details.

 

  • SAP Asset Performance Management:
    • Assessments for consequence classification of industrial system functions (Details)
    • AI-automated visual asset condition monitoring (Details)
  • SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud:
    • Graphical view for setting relationships between operations of one or multiple maintenance orders (Details)
    • Joule-based AI agents to propose optimized maintenance event for an asset to minimize operational disruptions (Details)
    • Support for the new Permit to Work (PTW) solution (Details)
  • SAP Field Service Management:
    • Management of measurement points on activity level (Details)
    • Dependencies between activities (Details)
    • Tool schedule visualization (Details)
    • Linear assets on the service map (Details)
    • Selection of multiple work orders through a lasso operation (Details)
    • Timesheet management in the partner portal (Details)
  • SAP Service & Asset Manager:
    • AI Assisted execution with Joule mobile client (Details)
    • Service assignment rescheduling support for field service technicians (Details)
    • Esri map improvements with breadcrumbing and draw-to-search capabilities (Details)
    • Support for the new Permit to Work (PTW) solution (Details)
    • Service assignment rescheduling support for field service technicians (Details)
  • Business Network for Asset Collaboration:
    • Integration of digital inspection checklists to support sharing with service providers (Details)
    • Modeling, sharing, and ERP system integration of failure catalogs and codes with causes and effects (Details)

 

  • SAP S/4HANA Utilities - Overall Topics:

    • Utilities Data Products (Master Data) (Details)
    • Archiving of installations and premises and deletion of unused device information records (Details)
    • Enterprise search for utilities master data (Details)
    • Continuous Influence (Details)
  • SAP S/4HANA Utilities - Metering:
    • Graphical display of utilities interval data (Details)
    • More flexible completeness check for profile values (Details)
    • Data Products and CDS views for energy settlement master data (Details)
    • Archiving of connection objects, device locations and devices (Details)
  • SAP S/4HANA Utilities - Market Process Management:
    • Utilities Data Products (Market Communication: process document header) (Details)
    • Utilities Data Products (Market Communication: transfer document header) (Details)
  • SAP S/4HANA Utilities - Contract Accounting:
    • SAP Fiori app for displaying the FI-CA document flow (Details)
    • Dispute resolution for missing payments (Details)
    • Dispute resolution agent for incorrect credits (Details)
    • Dispute resolution agent for missing credits (Details)
    • SAP Fiori app ‚ÄúManage Contract Accounts‚Äù (Details)
    • OData v4 API for contract accounts (Details)

 

  • Customer Data Cloud:
    • Support for step-up authentication (Details)
    • Consent attributes connections ‚Äì definition and maintenance of user-consent data (Details)
    • Ability to collect consent that is provided on behalf of a third party (Details)
  •  Emarsys:
    • AI-assisted campaign translator (Details)
  • CX AI Toolkit:
    • Shopping agent: related accessories based on product relationships (general availability) (Details)
  • Commerce:
    • Integration with SAP Omnichannel Promotion Pricing to display promotion recommendations on the product details page (Details)
  • CPQ:
    • Conversational AI support for quote handling (Details)
    • Integration with SAP Subscription Billing for a smooth quote-to-cash experience (Details)
  • Sales Cloud:
    • Promotion management (sales) (Details)
    • Maintaining marketing attributes for accounts, contacts, products, and registered products (sales) (Details)
  • Service Cloud:
    • Case priority prediction (service) (Details)
    • Case routing based on skills (service) (Details)
  • Sales and Service Cloud:
    • Additional features to support attachment search and management (sales and service) (Details)
    • Navigation to Custom UIs from a Mashup (sales and service) (Details)
    • Machine translation for notes (sales and service) (Details)
    • Home page AI capability for creating KPI cards (sales and service) (Details)

 

  • Distributed Energy Resources:
    • Enabling validation checks of instances through an API (Details)
    • Analytics for Long-Running Processes (Details)
    • Lightweight process for updating active measurement concept instances (Details)
  • Green Ledger:
    • Finance Intelligence: SAP Green Ledger (Details)
    • Connecting to several tenants of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management (Details)
    • Accounting for carbon allowances (CBAM) in a carbon journal (Details)
  • Sustainability Footprint Management:
    • Retrieving carbon flows from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and posting them as allocations (Details)
    • Connecting to several tenants of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management (Details)
    • Supplier footprint integration with data exchange standards (Details)
  •  Sustainability Control Tower:
    • Cloud ERP Intelligence & Finance Intelligence: SAP Sustainability Control Tower (Details)
    • Data product for carbon journal entry (Details)

entry.title: How to Filter Current vs. Previous Year Data Using a Single Posting Date Input Control in SAP Analyt
entry.content:
Hi everyone!!

I‚Äôm working on a requirement in SAP Analytics Cloud where I need to use a single Posting Date input control to filter two different tables in a story. The first table should display data for the exact month selected by the user through that input control, while the second table should automatically show data for the same month in the previous year. Both tables use the same dimensions‚ÄîG/L Account and Posting Date‚Äîand the measure Amount in Company Code. For example, if the user selects January 2025, the first table should show January 2025 data, while the second should show January 2024 data.

The challenge is that SAC applies the input control directly to the Posting Date dimension for both tables, and I need a way to ‚Äúoffset‚Äù the Posting Date filter by one year only for the second table. I‚Äôm looking for the best approach to achieve this,  any SAC feature that allows filtering one table based on a previous-year version of the selected date. If anyone has implemented something similar or knows an efficient workaround, I would really appreciate your guidance.

entry.title: Introducing AI-Powered Anomaly Insights & Recommendations in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP Integration Suite offers API Anomaly Detection that involves monitoring and identifying abnormalities in time series data related to APIs, enabling API Owners detect unexpected patterns or deviations from the norm, ensuring optimal performance and business continuity. Traditionally, resolving these anomalies has been time-consuming involving manual activities around impact assessment, root cause analysis & identification of mitigation plans.  

That‚Äôs about to change!

What‚Äôs New

SAP Integration Suite now brings AI-powered anomaly insights and intelligent recommendations to help you move from detection to resolution faster than ever. It improves troubleshooting efficiency and reduces manual investigation time. This feature leverages advanced machine learning models to identify anomalies and AI models to suggest actionable steps to fix them‚Äîempowering API Owners & developers to stay ahead of issues.

Note : The feature is in the process of getting updated in our global Data centres. Check this Note for information about regional availability.

Note : The availability of the Anomaly Detection & Intelligent Recommendations feature is dependent on your SAP Integration Suite service plan. Check this note for information about the various plans and supported features.

Key Benefits

  • Detailed Insights & Causes: Ready to use analysis of the Anomaly, its impact and the probable root cause(s)
  • Intelligent Recommendations: Get context-aware suggestions for quick resolution
  • Reduced Downtime: Minimize business impact with faster troubleshooting
  • Continuous Learning: Recommendations improve over time as the system learns from user feedback

Feature Overview

To assist API Owners who have enabled Anomaly Detection in their tenants with faster resolution of Anomalies, we introduce AI-driven analysis of the Anomalies.

When an Anomaly is detected, an advanced AI-model generates comprehensive insights on the event around the system state, clients involved, the intensity of the Anomaly etc.  It also then highlights the potential root causes for the Anomaly, which gives clarity on where the corrections/resolutions must be applied. Finally, it also provides a set of recommendations that the API Owners & developers can apply ‚Äì both within & outside APIM systems - to resolve the issue at hand & also prevent future events.

Enablement

As an API Administrator of an SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì API Management tenant, one could enable this new extension by just selecting an additional check box under Anomaly Detection settings. If you are switching on Anomaly Detection for the first time, then the check box is selected by default. You need to accept the Generative AI usage terms before starting to use the feature.

Anomaly Analysis

In the event of an Anomaly, if the Intelligent Recommendations has been enabled on the tenant, you will see three new tabs under the Anomaly details ‚Äì Insights, Causes & Recommendations.

Insights: Delivers an in-depth analysis of unusual API traffic patterns, the system state during the anomaly, and its potential impact on API performance and stability.

Causes: Highlights the likely factors behind the anomaly by examining API usage trends, traffic variations, and underlying system conditions.

Recommendations: Offers practical steps and configuration adjustments to resolve the issue, enhance API performance, and implement preventive measures to avoid similar anomalies in the future.

In the example below, an API Traffic surge Anomaly has been detected. Observe how each of the tabs helps in getting clarity on the event itself & also quickly identify what could be done next.

For each of the generated content, feedback could be provided that helps the AI model learn over time & improve accuracy.

Summary

Instead of spending hours diagnosing issues, API owners can now rely on AI-driven guidance to resolve problems efficiently. This means less manual effort, fewer disruptions, and more time for innovation. More information could be found in our help documentation here.

Enable anomaly detection and intelligent recommendations in your SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì API Management tenant and experience smarter, faster ways to work with your APIs. Do give this a try & let us know what you think.

entry.title: Re: How to Post Components Linked to a Subproduct in SAP...
entry.content:
Good day @sergio21 

Thank you for your question.

The reason for what you explained is, all component quantities in a production order are planned and adjusted in relation to the main product in public cloud by default. The BOM logic does not allow by-products or co-products to act as a reference to scale when consuming component. That means

  • You cannot directly assign a sub-BOM to a by-product.
  • The components you assigned to production will always scale based on the quantity of AAAA you reported and not SU01.

My recommendation would be to manually adjust quantities of SM01 and SM02 based on the quantity of SU01 before or during confirmation.  A pro to doing that is; you will not have to change your master data and it will work with your current process. A con is, it will require your manual effort and could be prone to error when you have a high volume.

Alternatively, if you must automate the logic, you may use a Custom CDS View or logic in your Manage Production Orders and trigger a Custom BAdI or CPI logic that adjusts component consumption which is based on the SU01 quantity. A con, is it will require some development because it is not an out-of-the-box solution.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris
